ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I got an understanding of the literature related to industrial organization and learned how economists study innovation. I also learned about a lot of large companies in the US through the final project of the course that looks at patents.
empirical examples of innovations in HDD industry, microeconomics of competition and innovation
New perspective on familiar economic concepts, real world application of abstract thoughts, new methodologies of assessing economic data
An understanding of innovator's dilemma, how competition affects incentive to innovation, etc.
I learned a lot about industrial organization and how its evolved over this. Very interesting examples of industry level turnover.
I learned about how economists use different tools to measure the amount of innovation in a certain industry
Evaluation of innovations and their history over time but it could have been more up to date

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: manageable workload, interesting professor, no group projects
Weaknesses: kind of boring at times because of tedious theories that you need to learn about

Strength: great professor, light workload but interesting assignment that doesn't feel like busy work, fair grading

Weakness: bad TA

a bit monotonous sometimes, but michi was very excited about his class so that presented itself sometimes. since the course regards a topic that is still not completely researched , it was hard for the students to operate in class.

The course material is fascinating but the structure itself needs more organization. Much of the course felt like it was building up to one large conclusion when the reality was once a section was taught and done, it had almost nothing to do with the next section.

Strength: it was an interesting class with interesting content. 

Weakness: the assignments. Some of them seem trivial and did not contribute to the understandings of the class. Also the last exercise in CytoScape was interesting, but I would have gotten more out of it if it was focused on a tool that more economists used, like R or Stata.

Not great teaching fellow who wasnt very helpful and always held remote office hours with 2 different classes and would just put people in breakout rooms. Amazing Professor amazing lectures and good explanations
The strengths of the class came from Professor Igami's insights into his own research on innovation but some of the weaknesses came from the fact that the lectures were sometimes not engaging for me.
The instructions for the homework were not super clear

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to a junior or senior economics major. I think it was a good balance of learning new things while still having a very manageable workload.

YES! This is the best upper level Econ electives that I've taken at Yale. Prof Igami is super passionate and knowledgeable in this area, he is super nice/understanding, and although some papers/lectures can get technical professor doesn't expect us to know all the complex math. my only complain is that the TA wasn't very supportive/helpful. He often had no answers to our questions and instead of trying to get back to us with answers he kept saying 'i don't know. I know just as much as you guys." The course content itself was super interesting, inspiring, and fun to read about in your free time too. I appreciated some ad hoc articles that Prof Igami assigned about new tech (chat bot especially) because they were super relevant and fitting to our class theme.

I think the course may be most valuable to anyone looking to enter business and the corporate world, whether theyre an economics major or not. The economic teachings in the course are all already taught in Intermediate Micro, so its less about the economics and more about real world impact.
I am neutral about this. I did enjoy learning the content, but pretty much all other aspects of the course were mediocre.
Yes very interesting perspective in economics
If the student is looking for an easy economics senior seminar this is one of them.
Yea I would if you want an interesting class but its not the most engaging one
